    Aditya Jaishankar

    Google Scholar

    Biography

    I am a soft matter physicist and surface scientist with experience in theoretical, computational (numerical) and experimental work. I am currently at ExxonMobil Corporate Strategic Research Lab working on mathematical models to enable the efficient capture CO2 directly from air. I also work on developing molecularly thick self-assembled surfaces that provide ultra-low friction for more fuel efficient engines.

    I received a Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in July 2014. I worked with Professor Gareth McKinley in the Non-Newtonian Fluid Dynamics Group. My thesis, titled The Linear and Nonlinear Rheology of Multiscale COmplex Fluids developed theoretical models for describing the behavior of soft materials and complex fluids whose building blocks are arranged in fractal patterns. You can read more about my research here.

    Earlier, I graduated from the Department of Mechanical Engineering at IIT Madras with a Bachelor of Technology degree.

    Current Research Interest

    I am currently interested in applying Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence to accelerate scientific discovery. A sampling of my projects and coursework in ML and AI is available through the links above.

    I am motivated by the challenge of advanced materials design and discovery; the future demands stronger, lighter, inexpensive materials with smaller CO2 footprints, sustainable and recyclable plastics, efficient and safe batteries with high energy densities, drugs with fewer side effects, early cancer detection techniques, and so much more. The complexity and scale of these grand problems make traditional methods of scientific discovery inadequate. For example, in materials discovery, the traditional pathway of molecule conception, lab synthesis, verification of synthesis, property measurements, and iteration of this cycle, is too time-consuming and expensive. The field of AI has shown great promise in speeding up this advanced materials discovery life cycle, ranging from molecular graph based neural networks for probabilistic predictions of material properties, to reinforcement learning algorithms for optimal reaction and processing conditions. Using deep neural networks as function approximators for systems of partial differential equations has also shown promise in solving intractable theoretical and numerical problems. I am fascinated by this emerging area of research.

    Selected Publications

    • Jaishankar, A., Jusufi, A., Vreeland, J.L., Deighton, S., Pellettiere, J. and Schilowitz, A.M., 2019. Adsorption of Stearic Acid at the Iron Oxide/Oil Interface: Theory, Experiments, and Modeling. Langmuir, 35(6), pp.2033-2046.
      DOI: 10.1021/acs.langmuir.8b03132
    • Jaishankar, A., Wee, M., Matia-Merino, L., Goh, K.K. and McKinley, G.H., 2015. Probing hydrogen bond interactions in a shear thickening polysaccharide using nonlinear shear and extensional rheology. Carbohydrate polymers, 123, pp.136-145.
      DOI: 10.1016/j.carbpol.2015.01.006
    • Jaishankar, A. and McKinley, G.H., 2014. A fractional K-BKZ constitutive formulation for describing the nonlinear rheology of multiscale complex fluids. Journal of Rheology, 58(6), pp.1751-1788.
      DOI: 10.1122/1.4892114
    • Holten-Andersen, N., Jaishankar, A., Harrington, M.J., Fullenkamp, D.E., DiMarco, G., He, L., McKinley, G.H., Messersmith, P.B. and Lee, K.Y.C., 2014. Metal-coordination: using one of nature's tricks to control soft material mechanics. Journal of Materials Chemistry B, 2(17), pp.2467-2472.
      DOI: 10.1039/C3TB21374A
    • Jaishankar, A. and McKinley, G.H., 2013. Power-law rheology in the bulk and at the interface: quasi-properties and fractional constitutive equations. Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences, 469(2149), p.20120284.
      DOI: 10.1098/rspa.2012.0284
    • Jaishankar, A., Sharma, V. and McKinley, G.H., 2011. Interfacial viscoelasticity, yielding and creep ringing of globular protein–surfactant mixtures. Soft Matter, 7(17), pp.7623-7634.
      DOI: 10.1039/C1SM05399J

    Teaching

    I was a teaching assistant to my Ph.D. advisor for the graduate level Advanced Fluid Mechanics course.
